bib_record.title: Thermal neutron cross section and resonance integral of the 159Tb(n,g)160Tb reaction

free_txt: Pakistan Research reactor-1 at PINSTECH.
The reactor core contains 20% LEU fuel.

0.free_text: Cross section is thethermal neutron capture cross section at 2200 m/sec

free_txt: Thermal and epithermal correction factors were used
in the determination of the thermal neutron capture
cross section (the cross section at 2200 m/sec)
and resonance integral (epithermal neutrons in the
1/E region) for the rare-earth nuclide Terbium-159.
Thermal and epithermal correction factors were
calculated by using the expression described by
Zweifel (Nucleonics,18,174,1960) and
Baumann (AEC Report DP-817, 1963).
Paramenter alpha, which determines deviation of
thermalized neutron spectrum from 1/E dependance as:
alpha - (1/E)**(1+alpha)
was measured as alpha = -0.1623+-0.0055
All decay data were taken from:
S.Y.F.Chu+, LBNL report 1999, and  Evaluated Nuclear
Structure Data File (ENDSF), a computer file of
evaluated experimental nuclear structure data,
processed by RADLIST, IAEA NuDat Retrieval.
Errors in data are: in half life: +-0.2;
in probability (298.58) : +-0.006
in probability (879.383) : +-0.006
in probability (1177.962) : +-0.003
Errors in data are: in half life: +-0.2;
in probability (298.58) : +-0.006
in probability (879.383) : +-0.006
in probability (1177.962) : +-0.003

in probability (846.77715) : +-0.003

Errors in data are: in half life: +-0.26;
in probability (1115.546) : +-0.0022
Errors in data are: Half life: +-0.0.00021;
The gamma ray spectrometry of the irradiated
samples was carried out using a high-resolution
ganuna ray detection system. The system employed a
40% relative efficiency high purity germanium detector
with energy resolution of 2.0 keV at the 1332.5 keV
peak of 60Co. The induced activities in the terbium
samples were determined by measuring the y rays at
298, 879, and 1177 keV associated with the decay of
160Tb while counting the samples at source-detector
distances of 25 and 15 cm.
The uncertainties in the overall measurements
include:
(i) statistical errors,
(ii) the error in the interpolated efficiencies,
(iii) errors in the nuclear data (see DECAY-MON and
DECAY-DATA),
(iv) target weighing errors.
Pakistan Research reactor-1 at PINSTECH.
The reactor core contains 20% LEU fuel.
The irradiations of the activation detectors of Au, Co,
Mn, and Zn were carried out to characterize the neutron
irradiation facility. The targets of Au weighing 1-4 mg
were prepared from thin gold foils of thickness 30 mu-m
The cobalt samples (6-10 mg) were made from 10-mil
cobalt wire.The wires were cut into roughly equal
pieces of length 2 cm and rolled spirally. The
manganese samples (2-4 mg) were made from manganese
metallicpieces. Zinc foils (approx.2 mg) of 8 mm diam.
were used. For the determination of the alpha deviation
parameter, these activation detectors were packaged
together in standard polystyrene irradiation capsules
of dimension 13.5 mm in diameter and height 11 mm for
bare irradiation and another set of detectors was
packaged into a cadmium box of dimension 14 mm diam.,
height 6 mm, and thickness 1 mm. Each of the activation
detectors was also encapsulated individually within
polystyrene and cadmium covers for the determination
of thermal and epithermal neutron fluxes and cadmium
ratios.
Reactions 1,2 are used for 1/E deviation parameter
All others are used for deviation parameter and
cross section monitor. Cross sections are not given.
The targets of the terbium were prepared from spectro-
graphically pure powder Tb4O7 from Merck. A small
quantity of terbium powder (2-6 mg) was spread onto
a Whatman-1 filter paper,covering a relatively large
circular foils of about 8-10 mm in diam. Four samples
were prepared for bare irradiation and another four
for irradiation under a cadmium cover. The weighing of
the target materials was carefully carried out using a
Sartorius semimicro electrical balance.
Data from the tbl.3 of this paper
